details.llm_def: Droṇa, primarily known as the revered military preceptor of the Pāṇḍavas and Kauravas, is also recognized in various contexts as a grain measure, a mountain, a cloud, and a bird. Born from a vessel due to his father Bharadvāja's encounter with the Apsaras Ghṛtācī, he is celebrated for imparting martial skills and wisdom, notably teaching Arjuna and becoming a pivotal figure in the Kurukṣetra war, where his fate intertwined with tragedy and honor.

definitions.source: Sanskrit Glossary from Sanskrit Documents Website

definitions.text:
Droṇa, also known as droṇa, was a multifaceted figure in hindū mythology. He served as the warrior-preceptor who trained both the Pāṇḍavas and Kauravas, including imparting the powerful Brahmāstra to arjuna [5][4]. As the Kaurava commander during the Kurukṣetra war, he orchestrated abhimanyu's demise by devising the Chakravyuha formation, leading to his death [1][2]. He was killed through deceit during the same war [5]. Additionally, Droṇa is associated with a specific shape of bricks used in the agnicayana ritual, representing a trough [3]. In the context of the mahābhārata, he is featured in the Prapannagītā's verses and is deemed less virtuous than Vidura, who refused to support the Kauravas in battle [7][8]. His previous life was as nanda, a vasu who performed severe austerities to have God as their son [6].

definitions.text:
Drona was a Brahmin whose home was located in Vethadvīpa, near Allakappa [1]. He is also known for receiving the city of Ahicchatra from Arjuna along with Kampilya [2], and for being the one who distributed Buddha's relics after his death, associated with the Drona-stūpa [3].

definitions.text:
Droṇa, as described in the Shiva Purana, is multifaceted, appearing in various roles across different sections. In Section 2.5 - Rudra-saṃhitā (5): Yuddha-khaṇḍa, Chapter 15, he is a mountain from which Aṅgiras retrieves divine herbs to revive the gods during battles [1]. In the same section but Chapter 50, he is one of the flowers offered by Bhārgava in his worship of Śiva [2]. In Section 3 - Śatarudra-saṃhitā, Chapter 36, Droṇa is portrayed as a brahminical sage performing a penance to obtain a son, Aśvatthāman, who is Śiva's incarnation [3]. He is also mentioned in the same section, Chapter 38, as one of Arjuna's formidable adversaries, alongside Bhīṣma and Karṇa [4]. Lastly, in Section 5 - Umā-Saṃhitā, Chapter 4, Droṇa is celebrated as the foremost among marksmen, born from the semen collected by Gautama in a wooden bowl [5].

definitions.text:
Drona is mentioned in the Garuda Purana in two distinct contexts. According to the Agastya Samhita, Chapter LVI, Drona is listed among the seven mountains [1]. Additionally, in the Brihaspati (Nitisara) Samhita, Chapter CXLV, Drona is described as the preceptor of the Kuru race and later as the commander of the Kuru forces during the Mahabharata war [2].

definitions.text:
Drona is a multifaceted figure mentioned in the Harivamsha Purana. According to Book 2 - Vishnu Parva, Chapter 57 - Krishna's Proposal to Go to Dvaraka, Drona is described as a person residing on the mountain Raivata for many years [1]. In contrast, Book 3 - Bhavishya Parva, Chapter 48 - The Fruits of the Recitation of the Bharata, identifies Drona as a Parva within the Bharata, which necessitates feeding the Brahmanas to their satisfaction and providing them with bows, arrows, and swords during its recitation [2].

definitions.text: Drona, according to the Mahabharata, is a multifaceted character known for his roles as a teacher, warrior, and advisor. Born from the seed of Bharadvaja, he becomes an expert in the Vedas and weaponry [1], learning from Rama and later teaching the Kuru princes, including the Pandavas and Kauravas [2][3]. He is described as a skilled Brahmana who impresses the princes of Hastinapura with his prowess and seeks to become their teacher [4]. Drona approaches Drupada seeking friendship but faces rejection, leading him to demand Drupada as a preceptorial fee from his students, which he later forgives and offers half his kingdom [5][6]. He is noted for his rivalry with King Drupada and his mastery of the Brahma weapon [7][8][9]. As a teacher, Drona shows favoritism towards Arjuna, testing his focus and skill, and certifying his proficiency in all weapons [10][11][12]. He leads the Kaurava army for five days in the battle described in the Drona Parva [13]. Drona is also recognized as a respected advisor, providing counsel to King Dhritarashtra on matters of state and suggesting alliances [14][15][16][17]. He participates in significant events such as the Rajasuya sacrifice and is mentioned as a powerful ally of Duryodhana
